Award.AwardTitle: NRI: Small: Reducing Trunk Musculoskeletal Forces During Manual Work

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
The research objective of this award is to develop a set of advanced engineering principles for design of the exoskeleton systems that reduce the internal musculoskeletal forces and oxygen consumption in a person during a variety of laborious tasks in various workplaces. The hypothesis is that these systems will decrease the severity and number of work-related back injuries while enhancing worker safety in automobile assembly plants and distribution centers. The research approach progresses from the exploration of the human-machine interaction when both the flow of power and information between the device and human dictate the overall functionality and performance of the device. Employing the dynamic models of various elements in this human-machine interaction, passive impedances and actuators will be developed for the exoskeletons. A set of experiments will be conducted to quantify the effect of the exoskeleton system on human trunk in sagittal plane, in frontal plane, and rotation around the spine.

If successful, the technologies proposed here will manifest in the development of broad classes of exoskeleton devices for workers who repeatedly move objects in factories, warehouses and distribution centers. This project will yield a set of engineering principles that decrease the risk of injuries due to repetitive maneuvers in distribution centers and in auto assembly plants. This project further will increase the availability of affordable assist systems for workers and improve the quality of life for workers. The educational impact of this research is derived from the proposed concerted effort to integrate education with research. Graduate and undergraduate engineering students will benefit through involvement in the research. The prototypes developed in this research project will enrich educational platforms for the study of design, modeling, and control of assist devices interacting with humans.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Our research objective was to develop a set of advanced engineering principles for design of the exoskeleton systems that reduce the internal musculoskeletal forces in a person during a variety of laborious tasks in various workplaces. The hypothesis is that these systems will decrease the severity and number of work-related back injuries while enhancing worker safety in automobile assembly plants and distribution centers.  Employing the dynamic models of various elements in this human-machine interaction, passive impedances and torque generators have been developed for the exoskeletons. A set of experiments have been conducted in the lab to quantify the effect of the exoskeleton system on human trunk in sagittal plane.  

During this research effort we worked closely with two corporations:  Mitsubishi Corporation and Saint Gobain.  Both of these corporations gave us access to their facilities to evaluate our experimental devices.  The feedback from the workers using our devices have been used to create better technologies for the workers. There are a great number of problems that have been detected by observation of these experiments.  Without access to these facilities our research work would have been no more than a simple academic research.  However with the use of these realistic end users we have been able to develop technologies that are actually used by real workers in real settings.   Figures in the accompanied documents show some of the facilities that have used our devices.

Intellectual Merits. 

No wearable assist device has ever been used in factories or distribution centers for the benefit of workers. This is mostly due to the fact that no simple and accessible exoskeleton technology has been proposed that can directly influence the real problems that workers face on a daily basis.  Large, bulky and human-like exoskeletons have been built in the hope of augmenting a person’s strength, but a thorough review of modern work places and statistics by the Department of Labor reveal that it is not the heavy weight of objects being maneuvered that causes injuries among workers.  Rather, it is the person’s body mass and dynamics that have caused serious injuries among workers even when they carry no parts.

To accomplish our goal, several technical challenges were solved. These include understanding workers’ real-life problems and translating them into a meaningful set of engineering specifications, designing an accessible and effective exoskeleton that directly addresses the workers vulnerabilities, analyzing the coupled dynamics of the human-exoskeleton, and developing robust control schemes for the exoskeleton which safeguard the human operator in the presence of human variation.  One of our experimental Trunk Support Exoskeleton (TSE) is shown in the attached photo. 

Trunk Support Exoskeleton (TSE) is a novel industrial exoskeleton that reduces the forces and torques on a wearer’s lower back region (L5/S1 disc) by 60% while s/he is stooping, lifting objects, bending or reaching. TSE greatly minimizes the risk of back injuries among workers in warehouses, distribution centers, factories, construction sites, shipbuilding facilities, foundries and auto assembly plants. TSE increases productivity and never impedes natural movements. TSE can be worn all day long and is virtually unnoticeable to the user.  Using TSE, the wearer can walk, ascend and descend stairs and ladders, drive automobiles, ride bicycles, run and perform any maneuver with no restriction from TSE.

 

Broader Impacts

The societal impact of our proposed research is to dramatically improve the quality of life for workers. The technologies proposed here will manifest in the development of broad classes of exoskeleton devices for workers who repeatedly move light objects in factories, warehouses and distribution centers. This project outcome will:  

-     Decrease the risk of injuries due to repetitive maneuvers in distribution centers and in auto assembly plants; 

-     Decrease workers’ compensation indemnity claims involving back injuries;

-     Increase the availability of affordable assist systems for workers; 

-     Create broader awareness in educational institutions regarding workers and manual labor in general;

-     Improve the quality of life for workers.

The technological impact of our research stems from our systems integration approach to developing a class of exoskeletons customizable for a range of working environments. This effort involves the deep integration and convergence of design, control systems, orthopedics, ergonomics and human-machine systems.

The educational impact of our proposal is derived from our concerted effort to integrate education with research. Our exoskeleton prototypes will enrich educational platforms for the study of design, modeling, and control of devices operating in uncertain environments. They are ideally suited to offer graduate and undergraduates genuine research experiences. We hope to inspire our students with our conviction that technology can bring profound benefits to compelling societal problems.
